messages.content: Summarize the key points about evaluation driven development.

function.arguments: {"sql_query":"SELECT text FROM transcript_segments WHERE text LIKE '%evaluation driven development%' OR text LIKE '%evaluation-driven development%' OR text LIKE '%evaluate%' LIMIT 5;"}
function.name: query_database

messages.name: query_database
messages.content: [{"text": "how we oh, yeah, I'm sorry. Microphones off, please. The foundations of Llm software and evaluation driven development. And what's changed now from traditional software software development. And how we really need to think about building software that's powered by machine learning and Llms which share a lot of similarities, as Stefan pointed out. But instead of you know, writing some specs."}, {"text": "We need to build quickly and then deploy and then monitor and evaluate and iterate rapidly on this cycle. So that's what this course is all about, and we'll see on the building side. Prompt engineering will be important. Embeddings will be important. Fine tuning business logic. When deploying. We want to think through unit tests and versioning and continuous integration. And those things are some of the very exciting things that Stefan will be talking about in his workshop next week."}, {"text": "to evaluate properly and develop a robust evaluation system."}, {"text": "our way out is Edd, evaluation, driven development. Where you have a iterative loop right where you build, you monitor, you evaluate, you improve now."}, {"text": "even before launching a product. And this is something we'll talk about as the course goes on. You can, you can build a synthetic data set and evaluation harnesses to help you even before real users exist. And if you don't know what an evaluation harness is, don't worry about it. It's essentially a script, something reproducible that you use to evaluate your system. So one example I like to give is."}]

Key points about evaluation driven development (EDD) from the workshop include:

1. EDD is an iterative process comprised of building, monitoring, evaluating, and improving, creating a loop of continuous development.

2. It contrasts with traditional software development, emphasizing the quick building, deploying, monitoring, evaluating, and iterating cycle, especially essential for machine learning and LLM-powered software.

3. The approach encourages developing robust evaluation systems and utilizing synthetic data sets and evaluation harnesses even before launching a product to ensure thorough evaluation without needing real users.

final_answer:
Key points about evaluation driven development (EDD) from the workshop include:

1. EDD is an iterative process comprised of building, monitoring, evaluating, and improving, creating a loop of continuous development.

2. It contrasts with traditional software development, emphasizing the quick building, deploying, monitoring, evaluating, and iterating cycle, especially essential for machine learning and LLM-powered software.

3. The approach encourages developing robust evaluation systems and utilizing synthetic data sets and evaluation harnesses even before launching a product to ensure thorough evaluation without needing real users.

Discord was mentioned several times during the workshop. Here’s a summary of the mentions:

1. Participants are actively engaging in Discord, sharing resources, and having meaningful conversations. It's a place for community interaction and dialogue.

2. The organizers use Discord for asynchronous chat announcements and Q&A. It's an essential tool for community building and course communication.

3. There was a discussion about organizing geographically-distributed pods and the possibility of reaching out to others within Discord for collaboration or conversation.

4. Access to Discord is managed by sending direct messages to specific organizers like Jeff, Nathan, and William.

5. The course uses Discord channels specifically set for different cohorts and provides slides and other resources there.

6. Suggestions for leveraging Discord effectively as the community grows are welcomed.

7. Participants are encouraged to help each other out on Discord, indicating it's a supportive environment.

8. For convenience, participants are asked to use their full names as their Discord handles to make it easier for the hosts to recognize participants from the course.

9. Feedback is gathered via Discord, and participants are encouraged to interact by liking comments or participating in discussions. 

Overall, Discord is presented as a crucial platform for interaction, support, and resource sharing throughout the course.

final_answer:
Discord was mentioned several times during the workshop. Here’s a summary of the mentions:

1. Participants are actively engaging in Discord, sharing resources, and having meaningful conversations. It's a place for community interaction and dialogue.

2. The organizers use Discord for asynchronous chat announcements and Q&A. It's an essential tool for community building and course communication.

3. There was a discussion about organizing geographically-distributed pods and the possibility of reaching out to others within Discord for collaboration or conversation.

4. Access to Discord is managed by sending direct messages to specific organizers like Jeff, Nathan, and William.

5. The course uses Discord channels specifically set for different cohorts and provides slides and other resources there.

6. Suggestions for leveraging Discord effectively as the community grows are welcomed.

7. Participants are encouraged to help each other out on Discord, indicating it's a supportive environment.

8. For convenience, participants are asked to use their full names as their Discord handles to make it easier for the hosts to recognize participants from the course.

9. Feedback is gathered via Discord, and participants are encouraged to interact by liking comments or participating in discussions. 

Overall, Discord is presented as a crucial platform for interaction, support, and resource sharing throughout the course.
